{{for|Lamarck's theory of Inheritance of acquired characteristics|Inheritance of acquired characteristics}} {{hatnote|This article deals primarily with Acquired characteristics by humans. You can improve this article by adding information about Acquired characteristics by plants and non-human animals.}} An '''acquired characteristic''' is a [[Heredity|non-heritable]] change in a function or structure of a living [[biotic material]] caused after birth by disease, injury, accident, deliberate modification, variation, repeated use, disuse, or misuse, or other environmental influences. Acquired traits, which is [[synonym]]ous with acquired characteristics, are not [[August Weismann#Experiments on the inheritance of mutilations|passed on]] to offspring through reproduction alone.
The changes that constitute acquired characteristics can have many manifestations and degrees of visibility but they all have one thing in common: they change a facet of a living organisms' function or structure after the organism has left the womb.
*The children of former [[bodybuilder]] [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] may have highly developed or otherwise above average musculature.{{citation needed|reason=This claim needs a reliable source; acquired characteristics do not change the inheritable genes in gametes.|date=August 2015}} *"Lucky", an adult, three-legged dog who got her name after surviving being hit by a car when she was a pup, just gave birth to five puppies. None had [[limp]]s, malformed/abnormal legs, or were missing a leg. *[[Bonsai]] are normal plants that have been grown to remain small through [[Bonsai cultivation and care|cultivation]] techniques.
Acquired characteristics can be minor and temporary like bruises, [[blister]]s, shaving body hair, and body building. Permanent but inconspicuous or invisible ones are [[LASIK|corrective]] eye surgery and organ [[Transplant surgery|transplant]] or [[List of surgical procedures|removal]]. Semi-permanent but inconspicuous or invisible traits are [[vaccination]]s and [[laser hair removal]]. [[Perm (hairstyle)|Perms]], [[tattoo]]s, [[scar]]s, and [[amputation]]s are semi-permanent and highly visible.
Applying [[Cosmetics|makeup]] and nailpolish, [[Hair coloring|dying]] one's hair or applying [[henna]] to the skin, and [[tooth whitening]] are '''not''' examples of acquired traits. They change the appearance of a facet of an organism, but do not change the structure or functionality.
[[Inheritance of acquired characters]] was historically proposed by renowned [[theorist]]s such as [[Hippocrates]], [[Aristotle]], and French [[naturalist]] [[Jean-Baptiste Lamarck]]. Conversely, this [[hypothesis]] was denounced by other renowned theorists such as [[Charles Darwin]]. Today, although [[Lamarckism]] is generally discredited, there is still debate on whether ''some'' acquired characteristics in organisms are actually inheritable.<ref>{{Cite journal|pmc = 1320859|title=The Inheritance of Acquired Characteristics | journal=Am J Public Health|date=June 1925|volume=15|issue=6|page=549|doi=10.2105/ajph.15.6.549-a}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1073/pnas.78.9.5826 | last1 = Nisbet-Brown | first1 = E. | last2 = Wegmann | first2 = T. G. | title = Is acquired immunological tolerance genetically transmissible? | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 78 | issue = 9 | pages = 5826–5828 | year = 1981 | pmid = 7029546 | pmc = 348875|bibcode = 1981PNAS...78.5826N }}</ref>
== Disputes == Acquired characteristics, by definition, are characteristics that are gained by an organism after birth as a result of external influences or its own activities that change its structure or function and cannot be inherited.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/acquired+characteristic |title=Acquired characteristic - definition of acquired characteristic by The Free Dictionary |publisher=Thefreedictionary.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/acquired+characteristic?qsrc=2446 |title=Acquired characteristic | Define Acquired characteristic at Dictionary.com |publisher=Dictionary.reference.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/Acquired+characteristics |title=Acquired characteristics | definition of Acquired characteristics by Medical dictionary |publisher=Medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref> Therefore, every condition an organism is born with must be considered an inherited characteristic.
[[Heredity|Inherited characteristics]], by definition, are characteristics that are gained or predisposed to by an organism as a result of genetic transmission from its parents and will be passed to the organism's offspring.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/Inherited+trait |title=Inherited trait - definition of Inherited trait by The Free Dictionary |publisher=Thefreedictionary.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/inherited+character?qsrc=2446T |title=Inherited character | Define Inherited character at Dictionary.com |publisher=Dictionary.reference.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/Inherited+trait |title=Inherited trait | definition of inherited trait by Medical dictionary |publisher=Medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref> Therefore, every condition an organism does not gain or develop because of inheritance of its parents' genetic [[Gene|information]] must be considered an acquired characteristic.
===Eye color=== It is fairly common for [[mammal]]ian eyes to [[Eye color#Changes in eye color|change]] color in the first years of life. This happens, with human infants and kittens being some well-known examples, because the eyes of the baby, just like the rest of its body, are still developing. This change can be as simple as blue to brown, or can involve multiple color changes in which neither the child's parents nor his/her doctors know when the changes will stop and what the final eye color will be.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whattoexpect.com/first-year/ask-heidi/baby-eye-color.aspx |title=Baby's Eye Color |website=What To Expect|date= |accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref>
Changes in [[eye color]] signal changes in the arrangement and concentration of [[pigment]] in the [[iris (anatomy)|iris]], which is an example of [[structural color]]. Even though this change happens after birth, it is strictly as result of genes. While changes in eye appearance (and function, and structure) that occur because of acquired characteristics like injury, illness, old age, or malnutrition are definitely acquired characteristics, the infantile color change as described above is ''usually'' considered inherited. {{further|Genotype-phenotype distinction|David Bowie#Eyes|l2=David Bowie's eyes}}
=== Certain genetic conditions === When diseases are caused by environmental influences, such as [[iodine deficiency]] or [[lead poisoning]], their resultant symptoms are [[Wiktionary:unequivocal|unequivocally]] agreed to be acquired characteristics. However, it is debatable whether changes in bodily functions due to disorders that are [[Genetic predisposition|partly]] or wholly [[Genetic disorder|genetic]] in origin are actually "acquired".
Wholly genetic disorders, such as [[Huntington's disease|Huntingtons]], are ticking time-bombs that are inherited from parents' genes and are present before birth but the symptoms that develop, aka are "acquired", after birth are simply delayed manifestations of the inherited trait.
Disorders that are partially genetic, such as [[Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis|ALS]] and [[Allergy|allergies]], mean the organism has inherited a [[Genetic predisposition|predisposition]] to develop, aka "acquire", a certain condition but that inherited increased likelihood can be reduced or further increased [[sufficient causes|depending]] on acquired [[Host factor|characteristics]] of the organism.
{{Details|topic=the correlation between health, genetics, and environment|Gene–environment correlation|Gene-environment interaction|Risk factor|Genetic predisposition|Environment and intelligence|Physical health#Determinants of health|Behavioural genetics}}
===De novo mutations=== New mutations, (often [[Somatic (biology)|somatic]], spontaneous and sporadic), not inherited from either parent are called [[:wikt:de novo|de novo]] mutations.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Zhao |first1=Xiaoyue |last2=Leotta |first2=Anthony |last3=Kustanovich |first3=Vlad |last4=Lajonchere |first4=Clara |last5=Geschwind |first5=Daniel H. |last6=Law |first6=Kiely |last7=Law |first7=Paul |last8=Qiu |first8=Shanping |last9=Lord |first9=Catherine |last10=Sebat |first10=Jonathan |last11=Ye |first11=Kenny |last12=Wigler |first12=Michael |title=A unified genetic theory for sporadic and inherited autism |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |volume=104 |issue=31 |pages=12831–6 |year=2007 |pmid=17652511 |pmc=1933261 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0705803104 |bibcode=2007PNAS..10412831Z |jstor=25436390 |laysummary=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/07/070724113757.htm |laysource=ScienceDaily |laydate=July 26, 2007 }}</ref> The consensus on whether certain prenatal spontaneous [[mutation]]s and [[genetic disorder]]s that occur as a result of [[Meiosis|meiotic]] and [[Chromosome abnormality|chromosome]] errors<ref name="New Genetic Risk Factor">{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2010/11/101104154221.htm |title="New Genetic Risk Factor for Both Autism and Schizophrenia" |quote="Researchers have uncovered a prominent genetic risk factor for autism spectrum disorders and schizophrenia. The study reports a small genomic deletion in patients with these neurological conditions. ..."|website=ScienceDaily|date=November 4, 2010|accessdate=May 17, 2012}}</ref> or during cell [[cleavage (embryo)|division]] after [[Fertilization|conception]], like [[cystic fibrosis]] and [[Down syndrome]], are considered to be acquired or inherited<ref name="Mutations Not Inherited from Parents">{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2011/08/110807143823.htm|title= Mutations Not Inherited from Parents Cause More Than Half the Cases of Schizophrenia|website=ScienceDaily|date=August 7, 2011|accessdate=May 17, 2012}}</ref> is unclear. Mutations and meiotic errors can be considered inherited since the organism is [[Non-communicable disease#Inherited diseases|born]] with them ''in its genes'', but they can also be seen as [[Prenatal development|prenatal]] acquired characteristics since they are ''not actually inherited'' from its parents.<ref name="New Model For Autism">{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/07/070724113757.htm |title="New Model For Autism Suggests Women Carry The Disorder And Explains Age As A Risk Factor" |quote="Spontaneous mutations are changes in a chromosome that alter genes. Germ-line mutations are newly acquired in a germ cell of a parent, and sometimes are transmitted to offspring at conception. ... "The fact that germ-line mutations increase with age places older parents at a higher risk of having children with autism..." said CSHL co-author of the study [Dr.] Michael Wigler. ... Wigler suggests that "what we now know about spontaneous mutations and autism offers an alternative to traditional thinking about genetic disorders as purely heritable from a parent."|website=ScienceDaily|date=July 24, 2007|accessdate=May 17, 2012}}</ref> With de novo mutations and division errors, the relationship between the [[offspring]]'s altered genes and gene inheritance from the parents is technically [[spurious relationship|spurious]].<ref name="New Model For Autism" /> These genetic errors can affect the mind as well as the body and can result in [[schizophrenia]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2011/07/110710132810.htm|title=New genetic clues for schizophrenia; De novo mutations more frequent, study finds|website=ScienceDaily|accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2008/05/080530132220.htm|title=Gene Mutations Responsible For 10 Percent Of Schizophrenia Pinpointed|website=ScienceDaily|accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref> [[autism]],<ref name="New Genetic Risk Factor" /> [[bi-polar disorder]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2011/12/111221140347.htm|title=Rare genetic mutations linked to bipolar disorder|website=ScienceDaily|accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref> and [[cognitive]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2011/04/110418114005.htm|title=Intellectual disability is frequently caused by non-hereditary genetic problems, study finds|website=ScienceDaily|accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref> disabilities.
{{Details|topic=mutations and cell division errors|Cystic fibrosis#Cause|Genetic origins of Down syndrome|Causes of autism|Chromosome abnormality|Mutation}}
=== Prenatal conditions=== The definitions of inherited and acquired characteristics leave a [[Wiktionary:gray area|gray area]] for [[trauma (medicine)|trauma]], pre-existing and gestational maternal conditions that affect the fetus, as well as chemical and [[pathogen]] exposures and trauma that happen before and [[Birth trauma (physical)|while]] an organism is [[childbirth|born]], such as [[AIDS]], [[syphilis]], [[Hepatitis B]], [[chickenpox]], [[rubella]], unregulated [[gestational diabetes]], and [[fetal alcohol syndrome]].<ref>[http://www.noah-health.org/en/pregnancy/problems/problems/disorders/index.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501043359/http://www.noah-health.org/en/pregnancy/problems/problems/disorders/index.html |date=May 1, 2012 }}</ref> Most infections won't affect a fetus if the pregnant mother contracts it, but some can be transmitted to babies via the [[placenta]] or during birth, and others cause more severe symptoms in pregnant women or can cause complications to the pregnancy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.babycenter.com/0_infections-that-can-affect-pregnancy_9223.bc |title=Infections that can affect pregnancy |website=BabyCenter |date= |accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref>
{{Details|topic=complications of labor and delivery, and health issues in pregnancy|:Category:Pathology of pregnancy, childbirth and the puerperium}}
== Types == The [[World Health Organization]] defines [[health]] as a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being, and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity.<ref>{{harvnb|WHO Maternal health}}</ref> Acquired characteristics don't need to affect the health of an organism, (a scar, [[Sun tanning|suntan]], or [[Perm (hairstyle)|perm]]) but examples that do are often the first that come to mind when thinking of acquired characteristics since they are the easiest to observe and the ones that we, ourselves, are most familiar with.
=== Physical === Physical acquired characteristics can stem from various environmental influences such as disease, [[Body modification|modification]], injury, and regular or infrequent use of body parts.
=== Mental === Mental traits are acquired by learning and adapting native traits to the environment of the individual.

[[Feeling|Sentiment]]s are the result of the compounding of primary [[emotion]]s, being "bound up with [[knowledge]] and [[idea]]s."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&d=6335670 |title=Psychology: A Study of Mental Life - 1921, Page i by Robert S. Woodworth. | Online Research Library |publisher=Questia |date= |accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref> Only through vast [[experience]] in the [[nature|natural world]] can humans [[Learning|learn]] to recognize objects in all of the various [[Orientation (geometry)|orientation]]s in which we encounter them on a day-to-day basis.<ref>[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2010/09/100922121937.htm] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418180134/https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2010/09/100922121937.htm |date=April 18, 2012 }}</ref> The ability to do something [[Wiktionary:well|well]] is an acquired characteristic, since a [[skill]] comes from one's knowledge, practice, [[aptitude]], etc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/skill |title=Skill | Define Skill at Dictionary.com |publisher=Dictionary.reference.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref>
=== Mind-body correlation === Many acquired characteristics, such as injuries and diseases, directly affect only the [[Mental health|mind]] but indirectly affect the body or directly affect only the body but indirectly affect the mind.
Suppose you develop an [[Speech and language pathology in school settings#Articulation disorders|articulation disorder]] [[Component causes|after being hit]] in the head with a [[fastball]] from a [[Minor league baseball|Pro]] baseball pitcher. Once your [[concussion]] wears off, this is your ''only'' [[symptom]]. There's nothing wrong with your body, and nothing wrong with most of your mind but you [[stutter]] and [[Slur (phonology)|slur]] and mispronounce your words so that people have a very hard time understanding you.
How would such a condition affect your life if you were a child? A child would be teased mercilessly by peers and have trouble communicating with friends and family.
A student would not be able to communicate easily with classmates ([[Collaboration|collaborative]] assignments), teachers, tutors, and certain classes (choir, public speaking).
What if you had a job where you needed to be able to talk to people? You wouldn't be able to easily talk to customers, other employees, or your boss. You couldn't answer phones or make calls, greet customers, do presentations. You couldn't call your pet's name. You wouldn't even be able to use a [[fast food]] [[drive-through]] or tell your waitress what you wanted to order! You couldn't say, "I love you," to your child, parent, or [[significant other]].
How would you [[Coping (psychology)|cope]] with the [[functional disorder]]? With the changes and the stress those changes caused?
The example in the above link deals with the loss of a single mental function. Imagine what would happen if a part of your [[Physical fitness|body]] stopped [[functional disorder|working]]. Even something as simple as a broken [[Phalanx bone|finger]] causes many changes in lifestyle to compensate for the difference in function: writing, typing, drawing, driving, [[hobby|hobbies]] like gardening, fishing, or sports, using video game and TV controls, texting and dialing phone numbers, using [[cutlery]] to eat, opening a bag of chips or soda can, preparing food for yourself or your family, playing with your child or pet, unlocking and opening doors, bathing, brushing your teeth and hair, dressing yourself, typing your shoes, and more.
{{Details|topic=stress and the relationship between mind and body|Stress (biology)|Stress (physiology)|Stress (psychological)|Quality of life|Mind-body interventions|:Category:Stress}}
The person unable to pronounce words clearly would suffer additional stress, [[anxiety]], [[frustration]], and emotional upset from his functional limitation. There would be anxiety over financial hardships like bills from medical [[Physical examination|exams]] and [[Medical test|tests]], and a possible [[leave of absence]] or [[Involuntary termination|termination]] from work. Physical effects of your articulation disorder could be paper cuts from your notepad, headaches over the stress, stubbed toes and sprained ankles from rushing to where you accidentally left you notepad, pulling a muscle from hauling a laptop around, etc. Worry could induce [[ulcer]]s. If you have to cut back on [[Consumption (economics)|spending]], your (and your family's) nutrition could suffer. There would be less money for fine dining, going out with friends, and indulging in toys and hobbies.
Those close to you - family, friends, lovers - would be negatively affected by your limitation and your relationship with them would suffer as well.
{{Details|topic=living with conditions that require special care and life adjustments|Disease management (health)|Chronic care management}}
== Origin == There are four main types of disease: pathogenic disease, deficiency disease, hereditary disease, and physiological disease.
=== Prenatal === [[Congenital disorder]]s, known more commonly as birth defects, are DEFINITION.
It is possible for an unborn child to contract [[fetal disease]]s and [[perinatal infection]]s.
[[:Category:Disorders originating in the perinatal period]]
==== Trauma ==== Suppose a pregnant woman is shot in her [[abdomen]] and the bullet hits the [[Fetus (biology)|fetus]], causing a non-[[death|fatal]] injury. Depending on the length of time between injury and birth, the baby could be born either with a still-healing wound or with a fully healed scar. Regardless of its state of [[healing]], the gunshot wound could be considered an inherited characteristic, since the baby is born with the condition, or could be considered an acquired characteristic, since the condition did not happen as a result of genes inherited from its parents.
The gray area is that a prenatal gunshot wound obviously isn't an inherited, ''genetic'' condition but it can't be an acquired trait because it didn't happen ''after'' the baby's birth. {{See also|Acquired disorder|:Category:Birth trauma|Prenatal and perinatal psychology}}
==== Chemical exposure ==== {{main|Prenatal exposure#Exposure to toxins}} '''[[Hormone]]s''' are chemicals released by a cell or a gland in one part of the body that affect cells in other parts of the organism.
{{Details|topic=how hormones can affect fetal development|Prenatal testosterone transfer|Freemartin|Endocrine disruptor|s, Psychoneuroendocrinology|Prenatal hormones and sexual orientation}}
'''[[Chemical substance|Chemical]]s''' are substances with distinct molecular compositions that are produced by or used in a chemical process. ::{{main|Asbestos#Health problems}} ::While all types of asbestos fibers are known to cause serious health hazards in humans,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs343/en/ |title=WHO | Asbestos: elimination of asbestos-related diseases |publisher=Who.int |date= |accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asbestosdiseaseawareness.org/wp-content/uploads/IARC-Special-Report-200911.pdf|format=PDF|title=International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) Special Report, 2009 as published in The Lancet Oncology, May, 2009|publisher=Asbestosdiseaseawareness.org|accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.collegiumramazzini.org/download/15_FifteenthCRStatement(2010).pdf|format=PDF|title= Collegium Razmzzini 2010 Statement on Asbestos|publisher=Collegiumramazzini.org|accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref> it is not known whether its toxicity is due to mechanical damage or unwanted signal channels which might disrupt normal cell activity.
'''[[Drug]]s''' are any substance that, when absorbed into the body of a living organism, alter normal bodily function. Drugs can be legal and be used as is medically [[Pharmaceutical drug|prescribed]] by a doctor or be [[Illegal drug trade|illegal]] to buy, sell, possess, and administer. They can be naturally occurring (such as [[caffeine]] and [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]]) or man-made (such as [[Chlorpromazine]]). Both legal and illegal drugs can be [[Recreational drug use|misused]] and [[Substance abuse|abused]]. They have varying levels of [[Substance dependence|dependence]] and some can cause [[addiction]]. ::{{main|Barratry (common law)}} ::Common commercial: "''Women who took drug ''X'' during their pregnancy and had babies born with these conditions may be entitled to financial compensation.''"
{{Details|topic=how chemicals and drugs affect can fetal development and post-natal organism function|:Category:Poisoning and certain other consequences of external causes|:Category:Teratogens|:Category:Congenital malformation due to exogenous toxicity}}

===== Maternal environment and exposures ===== There is also reason to believe that the immune system of a baby will be healthier if, during pregnancy, the mother's immune system was regularly stimulated by exposure to pathogens. {{quote|"...A mother's farm exposure affects her baby's [[Regulatory T cells|T regulatory cells]]. These cells, it is now believed, act to suppress immune responses and thereby maintain [[immune system]] [[homeostasis]] to contribute to healthy immune development. ... The babies of mothers exposed to farms have more and better functioning regulatory T cells."|<ref>{{cite web|title=Farm Moms May Help Children Beat Allergies|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2008/05/080520090438.htm |accessdate=May 18, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212063826/https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2008/05/080520090438.htm |archivedate=February 12, 2012 }}</ref>}}
=== Postpartum === [[Acquired disorder]]
[[Season of birth]]
=== Childhood === {{Main|Helminthic therapy}} It is posited that the absence of exposure to [[parasite]]s, [[bacteria]], and [[virus]]es is playing a significant role in the development of autoimmune diseases in the more sanitized [[Westernized#Modern definitions|Western]] [[developed country|industrialized nations]].<ref name="pmid15687885">{{cite journal |author1=David E. Elliott |author2=Robert W. Summers |author3=Joel V. Weinstock. | title= Helminths and the Modulation of Mucosal Inflammation |journal= Current Opinion in Gastroenterology |volume=21 |issue=2 |pages=51–58 | year=2005 |pmid= 15687885|doi=}}</ref><ref name="pmid17153852">{{cite journal |author = Mohan C. |title= Environment versus genetics in autoimmunity: a geneticist's perspective |journal= Lupus |volume=15 |issue=11 |pages=791–793 |year=2006 |pmid=17153852 |doi=10.1177/0961203306070005}}</ref> Lack of exposure to naturally occurring [[pathogen]]s may result in an increased [[Incidence (epidemiology)|incidence]] of autoimmune diseases.<ref name = "pmid 16778161">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1164/rccm.200603-331OC | pmid = 16778161 | year = 2006 | last1 = Leonardi-Bee | first1 = J. | last2 = Pritchard | first2 = D. | last3 = Britton | first3 = J. | title = Asthma and current intestinal parasite infection: systematic review and meta-analysis | volume = 174 | issue = 5 | pages = 514–523 | journal = American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine }}</ref><ref name="pmid2513902">{{cite journal |author = Strachan D P. |title= Hay fever, hygiene, and household size |journal= BMJ |volume=299 |issue=6710 |pages=1259–1260 |year=2006 |pmid=2513902 |doi=10.1136/bmj.299.6710.1259 |pmc= 1838109}}</ref> (See [[hygiene hypothesis]].)
A complete explanation of how environmental factors play a role in autoimmune diseases has still not been proposed. However [[epidemiology|epidemiological]] studies, such as the meta analysis by Leonardi-Bee, et al.,<ref name="pmid 16778161"/> have helped to establish the [[Inverse function|link]] between parasitic infestation and [[autoimmune disease]] development, in other words, exposure to parasites reduces [[Incidence (epidemiology)|incidence]] of an autoimmune disease developing. {{See also|Hygiene hypothesis|Autoimmune diseases|Immune disorder|Diseases of affluence|Diseases of poverty|Social determinants of health|Inequality in disease|[[Lifestyle disease|diseases of longevity]]}}
"Early life exposure to [[microbe]]s (i.e., germs) is an important [[determinant]] of adulthood sensitivity to allergic and autoimmune diseases such as [[hay fever]], [[asthma]] and [[inflammatory bowel disease]]."<ref name="Getting the Dirt On Immunity">[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2012/03/120322142157.htm] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120529064054/https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2012/03/120322142157.htm |date=May 29, 2012 }}</ref>
"Immunological diseases, such as [[eczema]] and [[asthma]], are on the [[Diseases of affluence|increase]] in [[Westernized#Modern definitions|westernized society]] and represent a major challenge for 21st century medicine. ...[G]rowing up on a farm directly affects the regulation of the immune system and causes a reduction in the immunological responses to food proteins,"<ref name="Growing Up On a Farm">[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2012/02/120208132549.htm] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120513121711/https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2012/02/120208132549.htm |date=May 13, 2012 }}</ref> which not only means less severe reactions to [[food allergy|food allergies]], [[lactose intolerance]], [[gluten sensitivity]], etc., but reductions in the likelihood of developing them in the first place.
[[Developmental impact of child neglect in early childhood]]
[[Sexuoerotic tragedy]]
=== Disease === [[Disease]] is any condition that impairs the normal [[Physical fitness|physical]] or [[Mental disorder|mental]] (or both) function of an [[organism]]. (Though this definition includes [[Injury|injuries]], it will not be discussed here). Diseases can arise from [[infection]], [[environmental disease|environmental conditions]], [[accident]]s, and [[Genetic disorder|inherited diseases]].
It is not always easy to classify the source of a health problem. For instance, people can develop [[gout]], which is known to cause permanent or near permanent changes to the human body,<ref>{{MedlinePlusEncyclopedia|000353|Hypothyroidism}}</ref> because of [[malnutrition|diet]], inherited [[genetic predisposition]], as a [[Complication (medicine)|secondary]] condition from other diseases, or as an unintended [[Adverse effect|side effect]] of certain medications.
[[Infectious disease]]s can be caused by [[pathogen]]s and [[microorganism]]s such as [[virus]]es, [[prion]]s, [[bacteria]], [[Parasitism|parasite]]s, and [[Fungus|fungi]].
{{further2|Transmission (medicine)|Natural reservoir}}
For infectious, environmental, and genetically predisposed conditions, [[Lifestyle disease|lifestyle]] [[Lifestyle (sociology)|choices]] such as exercise, nutrition, [[Stress (biology)|stress]] level, [[hygiene]], home and [[Occupational disease|work]] [[Environmental factor|environments]], use or abuse of [[Pharmaceutical drug|legal]] and [[Recreational drug use|illegal]] drugs, and access to [[healthcare]] (including an individual's financial ability and personal willingness to seek medical attention) especially in the early stages of an illness all combine to determine a person's '''[[risk factor]]s''' for developing a disease or condition.
[[Precancerous condition]] [[Progressive disease]] [[localized disease]] to [[Systemic disease|spread]] to other area of the body.
=== Diet === {{quote|The [[World Food Programme|World Food Program]] and [[UNICEF]] reported last year that [[Chronic (medicine)|chronic]] [[malnutrition]] had left 42 percent of [[North Korea]]n children [[Stunted growth|stunted]] — meaning their growth was seriously [[Disability|impaired]], most likely permanently. An earlier report by the [[United Nations|U.N.]] [[United Nations agencies|agencies]] warned that there was strong evidence that physical stunting could be [[Developmental disability|accompanied]] by intellectual impairment.|Demick, Barbara. 2-14-2004. ''The Seattle Times''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Demick |first=Barbara |url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20040214&slug=korea14 |title=Nation & World | Effects of famine: Short stature evident in North Korean generation | Seattle Times Newspaper |publisher=Community.seattletimes.nwsource.com |date=2004-02-14 |accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref>}}
{{quote|"[[North Korea]]ns are on average three inches shorter than their [[cousin]]s in the [[South Korea|South]]." This statistic, or versions of it, have been quoted for some time. In 2010, the late [[Christopher Hitchens]] put the difference at six inches in an article in ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', titled "A Nation of [[Racism|Racist]] [[Insular dwarfism|Dwarfs]]". Martin Bloem is head of nutrition at the World Food Programme, which has been providing food [[aid]] to North Korea since [[North Korean famine|1995]]. He says poor diet in the [[Child development stages|early]] years of life leads to stunted growth. "Food and what happens in the first two years of life is actually critical for people's height later," he says. Today, according to the World Food Programme, "one in every three children [in North Korea] remains chronically malnourished or 'stunted', meaning they are too short for their age".|Knight, Richard. 4-22-2012. ''BBC News''<ref>{{cite web|author =Kerry Brown |url=http://m.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-17774210 |title=Are North Koreans really three inches shorter than South Koreans? - BBC News |publisher=M.bbc.co.uk |date=2012-04-23 |accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref>}}
[[Outline of nutrition]]
cougar with shortened legs at Big Cat Rescue
Poor nutrition and frequent injury and disease can reduce the individual's adult stature, but the best environment cannot cause growth to a greater stature than is determined by heredity.
Vitamin K deficiency malnutrition Nutrition disorder
Sleep debt
=== Injury === [[Trauma (medicine)|Trauma]] is "a body wound or shock produced by sudden physical injury, as from violence or accident,"<ref name=Dictionary>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Trauma|encyclopedia=Dictionary.com|year=2010|publisher=Dictionary.com, LLC|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/trauma|accessdate=2010-10-31}}</ref> or, more simply put, is "a physical wound or injury, such as a fracture or blow."<ref name=conmed>{{cite dictionary|title=Concise Medical Dictionary|edition=Eighth|editor=Elizabeth Martin|year=2010|publisher=Market House Books Ltd}}</ref>
[[Accident]]al injuries, most of which can be predicted and thus prevented, are the unintentional negative outcomes of unforeseen or unplanned events or circumstances which may have been avoided or prevented if reasonable [[Injury prevention|measures]] had been taken or if the [[risk]]s involving the [[Attendant circumstance|circumstance]]s leading up to the accident been recognized and acted upon (minimized).
[[Battery (crime)|Battery]] is a criminal offense involving the use of force against another that results in harmful or offensive contact.<ref>[[Black's Law Dictionary]] Garner, p. 162</ref> ([[Assault]] is fear/belief of impending battery.) [[Violence]] is defined by the [[World Health Organization|WHO]] as the [[Intention (criminal law)|intentional]] use of physical force or power, threatened or actual, against oneself or others that either results in or has a high likelihood of resulting in injury, death, psychological harm, [[maldevelopment]] or deprivation.<ref name="who.int">{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/violence_injury_prevention/violence/world_report/en/ |title=WHO | World report on violence and health |publisher=Who.int |date=2002-10-03 |accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref> Consent
{{See also|List of preventable causes of death|Risk management|Asphyxia}}
==== Head trauma ==== [[Head injury|Head trauma]] in the form of a traumatic brain injury, [[stroke]], drug or alcohol abuse, and infection have been known in some cases to cause changes to a person's mental processes, the most common being [[amnesia]], ability to deal with stress and changes in aggression. There have also been documented cases of a person's [[personality]] changing more drastically, the best-known case being [[Phineas Gage]], who in 1848 who survived a 1.1 meter long tamping iron being driven through his skull (though almost all presentations of Gage's subsequent personality changes are grossly exaggerated).
There is also the rare condition called [[Foreign Accent Syndrome]] in which someone who has suffered a brain injury will appear to speak in a new language or [[dialect]]. This is typically thought to be due to an injury to the linguistic center of the brain causing speech impairment that just happens to sound like a persons non-native language. This is thought to be the reasoning behind the [[urban legend]] where someone wakes from a coma or surgery and suddenly speaks a new language.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/health/2011/06/01/136824428/a-curious-case-of-foreign-accent-syndrome |title=A Curious Case Of Foreign Accent Syndrome : Shots - Health News |publisher=NPR |date=2011-06-01 |accessdate=2015-08-27}}</ref>
{{See also|Dementia pugilistica}}
==== Body modification ==== [[Body modification]] is the deliberate altering of the human body for any non-medical reason, such as aesthetics, sexual enhancement, a [[rite of passage]], religious [[ritual|reasons]], to display group membership or affiliation, to create [[body art]], shock value, or self-expression.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.essortment.com/all/whatisbodymod_pdv.htm |title=What Is Body Modification? |publisher=Essortment.com |date=1986-05-16 |accessdate=2015-08-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128093431/http://www.essortment.com/all/whatisbodymod_pdv.htm |archivedate=2016-01-28 }}</ref>
The [[Wiktionary:frequency|frequency]] of occurrence depends on the location, [[Wiktionary:extent|extent]], and number of modifications, and, perhaps most importantly, on the mind of each individual being asked to accept the modifications on another.
{{further2|[[Social acceptance]]|[[Peer pressure]]|[[Toleration]]|[[Controversial#Psychological bases of controversy|Controversy]]|[[Taboo]]}}
The change can be extreme but still be [[Social acceptance|accepted]] or at least [[toleration|tolerated]] by the majority ([[Cosmetic surgery|cosmetic]] surgery), or be extreme and opposed by most people ([[neck ring]]s). [[Ear piercing]] is a minor aesthetic alteration that is widely accepted (on females' ears). The [[Controversial#Psychological bases of controversy|acceptance]] of highly diverse [[tattoo]]s and [[body piercing]]s depends on location, size, and number and, perhaps most importantly, on the mind of each individual being asked to accept it.
Also known as maiming, [[mutilation]] is any form of physical [[injury]] aimed at [[Wiktionary:degrade|degrading]] the bodily appearance or function of a living organism's body. Examples, include [[amputation]], [[foot binding]], and [[genital modification and mutilation|genital cutting]]. The reasons for these changes can be [[rite of passage]],
Like other acquired characteristics, body modification results in permanent physiological changes that cannot be passed on to offspring genetically alone.
=== Use and disuse of body parts === Constant physical exercise such as swimming, running, and weight lifting can cause muscles to develop. However, muscles and other body parts can also waste away through [[atrophy]] due to disuse of said body parts. Both of these phenomena occur most of the time due to the living style of the organism and their effects on the physiology of the organism constitute of acquired characteristics such as either stronger muscles or disintegrated tissue.
Many repetitive activities (sports, [[manual labor]], [[Horse teeth#Typical wear patterns|chewing]]) create wear patterns and leave impressions on the [[bone]]s and [[fascia]] that are highly [[Forensic anthropology|specialized]] (sometimes even unique) to the activity. Over a lifetime, even such simple activities as [[Neutral spine|posture]] and [[Gait (human)|gait]] leave telltale impressions on our bodies. [[Forensic footwear evidence|shoes]].
[[:Category:Occupational diseases]] [[Occupational disease]] hobbies, sports
=== Other === [[Maternal physiological changes in pregnancy|Pregnancy]], [[Recreational drug use|drug]] consumption, exposure to [[Dangerous goods|chemicals]], and other environmental influences can cause acquired characteristics to occur.
[[Complications of pregnancy]] Wilson's disease

{{refimprove|date=February 2014}} [[File:Dogsled racing Alaska.jpg|thumb|Man's best friend: dogsled racing in Alaska]]
'''Anthrozoology''' (also known as '''human–non-human-animal studies''', or''' HAS''') is the subset of [[ethnobiology]] that deals with interactions between humans and other animals. It is an [[interdisciplinary]] field that overlaps with other disciplines including [[anthropology]], [[ethnology]], [[medicine]], [[psychology]], [[veterinary medicine]] and [[zoology]]. A major focus of anthrozoologic research is the quantifying of the positive effects of human-animal relationships on either party and the study of their interactions.<ref>Mills, Daniel S. [https://books.google.com/books?id=vrueZDfPUzoC&pg=PA28 "Anthrozoology"], ''The Encyclopedia of Applied Animal Behaviour and Welfare''. CABI 2010, pp. 28–30.</ref> It includes scholars from fields such as anthropology, sociology, biology, history and philosophy.<ref>DeMello, Margo. ''Teaching the Animal: Human–Animal Studies Across the Disciplines''. Lantern Books, 2010, p. xi. and Hurn, Samantha. ''Humans and Other Animals''. Pluto Press, 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.animalsandsociety.org/content/index.php?pid=41 Animals & Society Institute.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130625044717/http://www.animalsandsociety.org/content/index.php?pid=41 |date=June 25, 2013 }} Accessed February 23, 2011.</ref><ref>Note: the term should not be confused with "animal studies," which often refers to [[animal testing]].</ref>
Anthrozoology scholars, such as [[Pauleen Bennett]] recognize the lack of scholarly attention given to non-human animals in the past, and to the relationships between human and non-human animals, especially in the light of the magnitude of animal representations, symbols, stories and their actual physical presence in human societies. Rather than a unified approach, the field currently consists of several methods adapted from the several participating disciplines to encompass human-nonhuman animal relationships and occasional efforts to develop ''[[sui generis]]'' methods. {{TOC left}} {{Clear}}
==Areas of study== * The [[interaction]] and enhancement within [[Captivity (animal)|captive animal]] interactions. * [[Affect (psychology)|Affective]] (emotional) or relational bonds between humans and animals * Human perceptions and beliefs in respect of other animals * How some animals fit into human societies * How these vary between cultures, and change over times * The study of [[animal domestication]]: how and why [[domestic animal]]s evolved from wild species (paleoanthrozoology)<ref>College of Zoological Studies at London Hanover University - Paleoanthrozoology: Domestication of Species [http://londonhanoveruniversity.eu/b-sc--anthrozoology.html]</ref> * Captive [[zoo]] animal bonds with keepers * The social construction of animals and what it means to be animal * The zoological gaze<ref name="Franklin1999">{{cite book|author=Adrian Franklin|title=Animals and Modern Cultures: A Sociology of Human-Animal Relations in Modernity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=93RlP4PZvgQC|date=20 September 1999|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-0-7619-5623-5}}</ref> * The human-animal bond * Parallels between human-animal interactions and human-technology interactions * The symbolism of animals in literature and art * The history of animal [[domestication]] * The intersections of [[speciesism]], racism, and sexism * The place of animals in human-occupied spaces * The religious significance of animals throughout human history * Exploring the cross-cultural [[cruelty to animals|ethical treatment of animals]] * The critical evaluation of [[animal abuse]] and exploitation * Mind, self, and [[Personhood#Non-human animals|personhood in nonhuman animals]] * The potential human health benefits of companion animal ownership
== Growth of the field == There are currently 23 college programs in HAS or a related field in the United States, Canada, Great Britain, Germany, Israel and the Netherlands, as well as an additional eight veterinary school programs in North America, and over thirty HAS organizations in the US, Canada, Great Britain, Australia, France, Germany, New Zealand, Israel, Sweden, and Switzerland.
In the UK, the University of Exeter runs an MA in Anthrozoology which explores human-animal interactions from anthropological (cross-cultural) perspectives. Human animal interactions (HAI) involving companion animals are also studied by the [[Waltham Centre for Pet Nutrition]], which partners with the US [[National Institutes of Health]] to research HAI in relation to child development and aging.<ref>{{cite web|title=Processes in Social & Affective Development: Human-Animal Interaction (HAI) Research|url=https://www.nichd.nih.gov/about/org/der/branches/cdbb/programs/psad/HAI|website=Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD)|accessdate=7 April 2018|date=December 30, 2017}}</ref>
There are now three primary lists for HAS scholars and students—H-Animal, the Human-Animal Studies listserv, and NILAS, as well as the Critical Animal Studies list.
There are now over a dozen journals covering HAS issues, many of them founded in the last decade, and hundreds of HAS books, most of them published in the last decade (see for example, ''Humanimalia''). Brill, Berg, Johns Hopkins, Purdue, Columbia, Reaktion, Palgrave-McMillan, University of Minnesota, University of Illinois, and Oxford all offer either a HAS series or a large number of HAS books.
In addition, in 2006, Animals and Society Institute (ASI) began hosting the Human-Animal Studies Fellowship, a six-week program in which pre- and post-doctoral scholars work on a HAS research project at a university under the guidance of host scholars and distance peer scholars. Beginning in 2011, ASI has partnered with Wesleyan Animal Studies, who will be hosting the fellowship in conjunction with ASI. There are also a handful of HAS conferences per year, including those organized by ISAZ and NILAS, and the Minding Animals conference, held in 2009 in Australia. Finally, there are more HAS courses being taught now than ever before. The ASI website lists over 300 courses (primarily in North America, but also including Great Britain, New Zealand, Australia, Germany, and Poland) in twenty-nine disciplines at over 200 colleges and universities, not including over 100 law school courses.

The '''Associated Colleges of the Twin Cities''' ('''ACTC''') is a consortium of private [[liberal arts college]]s in the [[Twin Cities]] ([[Minneapolis–Saint Paul]]) of [[Minnesota]] dedicated to providing cooperative programs, services, and opportunities for their respective students, faculty, staff, and administrators. The ACTC is located in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]]. The five members of the ACTC are: *[[Augsburg University]] *[[Hamline University]] *[[Macalester College]] *[[St. Catherine University]] *[[University of St. Thomas (Minnesota)|University of St. Thomas]]
The ACTC was officially incorporated in 1975 in order to share and enrich academic offerings for the students of the five institutions. The consortium continues to promote student exchange between its member campuses and to develop and share academic programs. The opportunity for cross-registration makes possible a range and depth of course offerings and majors unavailable at any single institution.
According to the ACTC's official website (see link below), "this partnership combines the benefits of our campuses' small, liberal arts atmospheres with the diverse opportunities of a large university. Students enrolled at one institution are able to experience the strengths and benefits of each school."
==External links== *[http://www.actc-mn.org/ Official website] *[http://www.augsburg.edu/ Augsburg University] *[http://www.hamline.edu/ Hamline University] *[http://www.macalester.edu/ Macalester College] *[http://www.stkate.edu/ St. Catherine University] *[http://www.stthomas.edu/ University of St. Thomas]

K. Sharma | total_staff = 422 | administrative_staff = 342 | students = | scientists = 80 | city = [[Karnal]] | state = [[Haryana]] | province = | country = India | coor = {{Coord|29|42|29|N|76|57|11|E|}} | campus = Zarifa Farm | former_names = | free_label = | free = | colors = | colours = | athletics = | sports = | nickname = IISS | mascot = | affiliations = | budget = | website = {{URL|http://www.cssri.org|CSSRI}} | logo = [[File:DiwaliLights.JPG|200px|<center>Karnal View</center>]] | footnotes = A Karnal View }} '''The Central Soil Salinity Research Institute''' (acronym CSSRI)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acronymfinder.com/CSSRI.html |title=CSSRI - Definition by AcronymFinder |publisher=Acronymfinder.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref> is an autonomous institute of higher learning, established under the umbrella of [[Indian Council of Agricultural Research]] (ICAR) by the [[Ministry of Agriculture]], [[Government of India]] for advanced research in the field of [[soil sciences]]. The Institute is located on Kachawa Road in [[Karnal]], in the state of [[Haryana]], 125 km from the [[India]]n capital of [[New Delhi]].
== Profile == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Official logo of ICAR.png|left|120px]] --> [[File:Salinity.jpg|thumb|150px|Salt-affected soils.]] [[File:Oryza sativa of Kadavoor.jpg|thumb|150px|right|Rice]] [[File:Wheat close-up.JPG|thumb|right|150px]] Central Soil Salinity Research Institute (CSSRI) had its origin in [[Hisar (city)|Hisar]], [[Haryana]], on 1 March 1969, as per recommendations of an Indo-American team, employed to assist the [[Indian Council of Agricultural Research]] in developing a comprehensive [[water management]] program for India. However, by October, 1969, the Institute was shifted to its present premises in Karnal and a year later, the ''Central Rice Research Station'', [[Canning Town]], West Bengal was merged with CSSRI.
The institute has a satellite unit in Bharuch, which was originally started in Anand in 1989, but moved to [[Bharuch]] in 2003 and hosts the coordinating unit of AICRP on ''Management of Salt Affected Soils and Use of Saline Water in Agriculture'' with a network of eight research centres located in different agro ecological regions of the country at [[Agra]], Bapatala, [[Bikaner]], [[Gangawati]], [[Hisar (city)|Hisar]], [[Indore]], [[Kanpur]] and [[Tiruchirapalli]]. The coordinating unit of AICRP on Water Management was a part of CSSRI from early seventies till 1990 when it was moved to [[Rahuri]] in Maharashtra.
The main achievements of CSSRI may be listed as: * Reclamation of [[alkaline]] soils with the addition of chemical amendments.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|title=Central Soil Salinity Research Institute — 1. Reclamation and Management of Salt Affected Soils — 2. Use of Poor Quality Waters in Agriculture |url=http://www.agritech.tnau.ac.in/about_us/pdf/hrd_national_trainings_icar_cssri.pdf |accessdate=July 1, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714223439/http://www.agritech.tnau.ac.in/about_us/pdf/hrd_national_trainings_icar_cssri.pdf |archivedate=July 14, 2014 }}</ref> * Reclamation of [[Saline soil|saline]] soils through subsurface drainage. * Development and release of salt tolerant crop varieties of [[rice]], [[wheat]] and [[Mustard (condiment)|mustard]].<ref name="autogenerated1"/> * Reclamation of salt affected soils through salt tolerant trees. * Development of for the salt affected areas of [[vertisols]] and coastal regions. The Institute has reclaimed nearly 1.5 million hectares of salt affected land for productive use, producing approximately 15 million tons of food grains annually.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> * Development of subsurface drainage technology for waterlogged saline soils. Reclamation has been completed on approximately 50,000 hectares of land in Haryana, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra and Karnataka.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> * Replenishment of depleting [[water table]]s by artificial [[ground water]] recharge.
CSSRI manages an International Training Centre under an Indo-Dutch collaboration since 2001. It offers post graduate level programs in association with State Agricultural Universities (SAUs), [[Indian Institute of Technology]] (IIT) and other Universities.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
The Institute has undertaken several national and international projects. * International Rice Research Institute (IRRI)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://irri.org |title=Rice science for a better world |publisher=IRRI.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref> sponsored rice improvement program<ref>{{cite web|title=Council for Partnership on Rice Research in Asia|url=http://irri.org/networks/council-for-partnership-on-rice-research-in-asia |accessdate=July 1, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140625140858/http://irri.org/networks/council-for-partnership-on-rice-research-in-asia |archivedate=June 25, 2014 }}</ref> * Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aciar.gov.au |title=ACIAR Homepage |publisher=Aciar.gov.au\accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref> sponsored Indo-Australian program for wheat improvement<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aciar.gov.au/project/cse/2011/077 |title=Sustainable and resilient farming systems intensification in the Eastern Gangetic Plains (SRFSI) |publisher=ACIAR.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref> * IRRI, [[Philippines]] and [[CIMMYT]], [[Mexico]] sponsored program of cereal based systems<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.cimmyt.org/tag/central-soil-salinity-research-institute/ |title=CIMMYT's Blog » Central Soil Salinity Research Institute |publisher=Blog.cimmyt.org |date=2015-03-27 |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref>
==Divisions== [[File:MagomeDrainage.jpg|thumb|upright|205px|left|An agricultural drainage channel.]] [[File:Groundwater flow.svg|thumb|right|Relative groundwater travel times.|184x184px]] [[File:Bingzhou Peninsula area - land reclamation - DSCF9204.JPG|thumb|Land reclamation in progress]] The Institute is engaged in multidisciplinary research activities which are carried out through four divisions.
===Division of Soil and Crop Management===
The Division conducts research on resource conservation technologies<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/surat/Technology-answer-to-coastal-Gujarats-problems/articleshow/27428861.cms |title='Technology answer to coastal Gujarat's problems' - The Times of India |publisher=Timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=2013-12-15 |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref> and cost effective farming system models. It prepares and maintains digital databases of salt affected soils and conducts periodic assessment of soil resources. It also focusses on [[agroforestry]] on salt affected soils.
===Division of Irrigation and Drainage Engineering===
The Division attends to the areas related to [[groundwater recharge]] technologies, [[subsurface drainage]] for amelioration of waterlogged saline soils and decision support systems for ground water contaminations. The Division has project partnership with INNO-Asia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geoinf.uni-jena.de/7232.0.html?&L=2 |title=APRA: Partner |publisher=Geoinf.uni-jena.de |date= |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref>
===Division of Crop Improvement===
Development of saline and alkaline tolerant crops such as [[rice]], [[wheat]] and [[Mustard (condiment)|mustard]] through conventional breeding and modern molecular and physiological approaches is the primary activity of the Division.<ref name="plantstress1">{{cite web |url=http://www.plantstress.com/Files/Salt_India.pdf |format=PDF |title=Success Stories on Development, Spread and Impact of Salt -Tolerant Varieties of Rice, Wheat and Mustard in India |publisher=Plantstress.com |accessdate=2015-05-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924074044/http://www.plantstress.com/Files/Salt_India.pdf |archivedate=2015-09-24 |df= }}</ref>
===The Division of Technology Evaluation and Transfer===
The Division undertakes studies on the various aspects of [[land reclamation]] in relation to [[rural development]].
==Vision, Mission and Mandate== {{quotebox|align = right|width = 25em|<center>'''Vision'''</center><center>Productive utilization of salt affected soils and poor quality water resources in varying agro-ecological situations</center><ref name="cssri1">{{cite web|url=http://www.cssri.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=49&Itemid=105 |title=About Institute |publisher=Cssri.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref>}} {{quotebox|align = right|width = 25em|<center>'''Mission'''</center><center>To generate new knowledge and understanding of the process of reclamation and developing technologies for improving and sustaining the productivity of the salty lands and waters.</center><ref name="cssri1"/>}}
'''Mandate''':<ref>{{cite web|title=Central Soil Salinity Research Institute — Mandate |url=http://cssri.nic.in/mandate.htm |accessdate=1 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140626234145/http://cssri.nic.in/mandate.htm |archivedate=26 June 2014 }}</ref> The Institute is mandated with:<ref name="cssri1"/> * Conduct of basic and advanced research on reclamation and management of salt affected soils and development of suitable [[agrochemical]], biological and hydraulic technologies for the use of irrigation water for the development of various agro-ecological zones for sustainable production. * Generation, assessment and propagation of preventive/[[ameliorative]] technology. * Maintenance and dissemination of information on resource inventories for the management of salt affected soils and waters. * Act as a fulcrum for researches on salinity management and coordination of research between the various universities, institutions and agencies in the country for developing and testing location–specific technologies. * Provide advanced training and consultancy in salinity researches in India. * Liaison with national and international agencies for the achievement of the above objectives.
==Regional Research Stations== CSSRI has three regional stations for a wider national coverage, each located at [[Bharuch]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cssri.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=110&Itemid=110 |title=Bharuch, RRS |publisher=Cssri.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref> [[Canning Town]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cssri.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=55&Itemid=55 |title=Canning Town, RRS |publisher=cssri.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=C.S.S.R.I., R.R.S., Canning Town |url=http://wikimapia.org/#lang=en&lat=26.803659&lon=80.923713&z=19&m=b&search=CSSRI%20RRS%20Canning%20town |accessdate=1 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070622201523/http://wikimapia.org/#y=47107623&x=37552343&z=18&l=0&m=a&v=2 |archivedate=22 June 2007 }}</ref> and [[Lucknow]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cssri.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=56&Itemid=56 |title=Lucknow, RRS |publisher=Cssri.org |date=1999-10-27 |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://wikimapia.org/5864417/C-S-S-R-I-R-R-S-Lucknow |title=C.S.S.R.I., R.R.S., Lucknow |publisher=Wikimapia.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref>
==Facilities==
===Publication and Supporting Service Unit===
PSS unit is responsible for information dissemination of the scientific researches of the Institute and has published 233 research papers on national and international journals, published 25 books and 60 bulletins.
===Computer Centre===
The Institute is equipped with a modern computer centre since 1988 which acts as the communication hub of the Institute. The centre is supported by an ICT infrastructure, [[LAN]] network and modern hardware and software. It provides system support in the procurement, maintenance, training, [[Management information system|MIS reports]], document processing, conduct of computer based exams and IT support for administration. It also maintains the web site of the Institute.
===Health Care Center===
The Institute manages a ''[[Health care|Health Care Centre]]'' with the facility to accommodate 5 inpatients, a senior [[allopathic]] medical officer, a part-time [[ayurvedic]] medical officer, pharmacist, support staff, clinical laboratory with diagnostic equipment and a pharmacy. A modern fitness centre also operates in the health care centre.
===Library===
CSSRI [[library]] os a well stocked one, holding a collection of 14668 books and 7967 bound journals, consisting of publications of [[FAO]], [[IRRI]], [[UNESCO]], [[ILRI]], ICID, [[International Food Policy Research Institute|IFPRI]], [[American Society of Agronomy|ASA]] and [[American Society of Agricultural and Biological Engineers|ASAE]]. The library subscribes to 69 national and 25 international journals other than 15 gratis journals. It also maintains a digital repository with digital magazines such as SOIL, AGRIS and Plant Gene.
===PME Cell===
[[File:Botanical Garden V.L. Komarov Botanical Institute.jpg|right|190px|thumb|greenhouse.]] Research Priority setting, Monitoring and Evaluation (PME) cell is the monitoring unit of the Institute for assisting the scientists and scholars in the allocation of research areas and the monitoring and evaluation of the projects. It helps the scientists in the maintenance of database, report generation and compilation, generation and publication of research documents.
===Technology Management Unit===
Technology Management Unit is equipped with and manages: * sodic and [[Saline soil|saline]] micro-plots for creating desired stress levels of sodicity and [[salinity]] * environmentally controlled [[Green house|glass house]] for growing crops and monitoring their genetic resources * [[Transgenic]] [[Greenhouse]], under Indo-US ABSP II program * Central laboratory with modern equipment
The Institute has an administrative department, a Hindi Cell and a workshop to attend to the relevant areas of activities.
==All India Coordinated Project for Research (AICRP)== [[File:Canaldoddaghatta.jpg|thumb|180px|Irrigation canal near [[Channagiri]], [[Davangere District]], [[India]]]] [[File:Faidherbia albida.JPG|thumb|Agroforestry]]
The Institute is the coordinating unit for the All India Coordinated Project for Research on ''Management of Salt Affected Soils and Use of Saline Water in Agriculture''. The research is conducted at nine centres viz. [[Agra]], [[Bapatla]], [[Gangawati]], [[Kanpur]], [[Indore]], [[Bikaner]], [[Pali district|Pali]], [[Hisar (city)|Hisar]] and [[Tiruchirapalli]].<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
The project is mandated with the responsibility to: * Conduct survey and characterize the salt affected soils and the quality of ground water in various [[irrigation]] commands. * Develop guidelines and standardize procedures for the assessment of irrigation waters. * Conduct studies on the effect of poor quality water on soil and crops. * Prescribe practice norms for utilization of water with high salinity/ alkalinity and toxic ions. * Prepare strategies for the [[Land reclamation|reclamation]] of salt affected soils. * Prescribe alternate methods of using salt affected soils by way of [[Agroforestry]], bio-drainage and multi-enterprise cultivation such as medicinal and [[aromatic]] plants. * Identify and develop crop [[cultivars]] and trees suitable for cultivation in salinity and alkalinity soil conditions.<ref name="plantstress1"/>
==Awards and recognitions== CSSRI has been recognised for its efforts by way of several awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cssri.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=24&Itemid=24 |title=Awards |publisher=Cssri.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref> * ICAR Best Institute Award for the year 1998<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiaenvironmentportal.org.in/content/107797/tnau-and-cssri-to-get-icar-best-institution-award/ |title=TNAU and CSSRI to get 'ICAR Best Institution Award' - India Environment Portal | News, reports, documents, blogs, data, analysis on environment & development | India, South Asia |publisher=India Environment Portal |date=1999-07-16 |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref> * "Sardar Patel Outstanding ICAR Institution Award" for the year 2009<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icar.org.in/files/citations-2010-ICAR-Awards.pdf |format=PDF |title=Citations : ICAR Award Ceremony 2010 |publisher=Icar.org |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref> * Groundwater Augmentation Award- 2009 of [[Ministry of Water Resources (India)|Ministry of Water Resources]] (Government of India)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2011/20110412/harplus.htm |title=The Tribune, Chandigarh, India - Haryana Plus |publisher=Tribuneindia.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref> * [[Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi]] Hindi Krishi Patrika Puraskar" for the year 2009<ref name="cssri2">{{cite web|url=http://www.cssri.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=24&Itemid=121 |title=Awards |publisher=Cssri.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-09}}</ref> * Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi Hindi Krishi Patrika Puraskar" for the year 2008<ref name="cssri2"/>

{{Unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} [[File:Chain_of_trust.svg|lang=en|thumb|400px|The roles of root certificate, intermediate certificate and end-entity certificate as in the chain of trust.]] In computer security, a '''chain of trust''' is established by validating each component of [[computer hardware|hardware]] and [[software]] from the end entity up to the root certificate. It is intended to ensure that only trusted software and hardware can be used while still retaining flexibility.
==Introduction== A chain of trust is designed to allow multiple users to create and use software on the system, which would be more difficult if all the keys were stored directly in hardware. It starts with hardware that will only boot from software that is [[Digital signature|digitally signed]]. The signing authority will only sign boot programs that enforce security, such as only running programs that are themselves signed, or only allowing signed code to have access to certain features of the machine. This process may continue for several layers.
This process results in a chain of trust. The final software can be trusted to have certain properties, because if it had been illegally modified its signature would be invalid, and the previous software would not have executed it. The previous software can be trusted, because it, in turn, would not have been loaded if its signature had been invalid. The trustworthiness of each layer is guaranteed by the one before, back to the [[trust anchor]].
It would be possible to have the hardware check the suitability (signature) for every single piece of software. However, this would not produce the flexibility that a "chain" provides. In a chain, any given link can be replaced with a different version to provide different properties, without having to go all the way back to the trust anchor. This use of multiple layers is an application of a general technique to improve scalability, and is analogous to the use of multiple certificates in a [[Root certificate|certificate chain]].
==Computer security== In computer security, digital certificates are verified using a chain of trust. The trust anchor for the digital certificate is the root [[certificate authority]] (CA).
The certificate hierarchy is a structure of certificates that allows individuals to verify the validity of a certificate's issuer. Certificates are issued and signed by certificates that reside higher in the certificate hierarchy, so the validity and trustworthiness of a given certificate is determined by the corresponding validity of the certificate that signed it.
The chain of trust of a certificate chain is an ordered list of certificates, containing an end-user subscriber certificate and [[intermediate certificate authority|intermediate certificates]] (that represents the intermediate CA), that enables the receiver to verify that the sender and all intermediate certificates are trustworthy. This process is best described in the page ''[[Intermediate certificate authority]]''. See also [[X.509#Certificate chains and cross-certification|X.509 certificate chains]] for a description of these concepts in a widely used standard for digital certificates.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chain Of Trust}} [[Category:Computer security]] [[Category:Trusted computing]]

{{Unreferenced|date=June 2010}}
'''Codevelopment''' is a trend of thought and a development strategy in [[development studies]] which considers [[Immigration|migrants]] to be a developing factor for their countries of origin.
Although it is widely accepted that it was [[France|French]] scholar [[Sami Naïr]] who first coined the word codevelopment, it is believed this phenomenon has existed alongside migrations since they exist. Traditionally, immigrants (especially those who migrate for economic reasons) have, collectively or individually, supported their communities of origin.
In 1997 Sami Naïr, while directing the Interministerial Mission on Migration/Codevelopment, defined this last concept as ''a proposal for integrating immigration and development in a way that migration fluxes will benefit both the country of origin and the country of destination. This is, a consensual relationship between two countries that will allow migration to the country of destiny not to imply an equivalent loss in the country of origin''.
Adherents to this model believe that it fosters mutual collaboration among countries in a way that traditional and hierarchical north-south development focus did not. In this context, immigrant initiatives enrich the countries of origin both from a cultural and a [[human resources]] perspective. Their condition as transnational citizens would allow them a better understanding of the needs of both the communities of origin and destination. For this reason, their participation in projects involving members of their communities, in both “their” countries would be more effective, as priorities and needs would be correctly identified. On the other hand, this participation would also work as an integrating force in the destination countries, as they would be perceived as an enriching factor by the public opinion and institutions.
== Codevelopment and migration control ==
In countries receiving immigration, codevelopment has been implemented by the institutions in a different way. Since they were first implemented in France, codevelopment initiatives in Europe have been frequently linked to control of the migration fluxes, often promoting the return of immigrants.
At a European level, codevelopment was first mentioned during the [[Tampere Summit]] held in October 1999, when the [[European Council]] defined 5 guidelines for the new European migration policy aimed at a common space of ''"Liberty, Security and Justice".'' Anyhow, critics consider that Tampere quickly shifted towards a [[Fortress Europe]] mentality, limiting [[development aid]] to those countries willing to implement migration control measures and accepting repatriations.
An example of this tendency may be found in the imbalance between de 23 million euro budget that the [[European Union|EU]] plans on investing in the [[Schengen Information System]] and the [[Visa Information System]] (aimed at a further immigrant identification and control) with the 3 million euro budget (4 million in its second year) granted to codevelopment projects.
== Codevelopment in Spain ==
Since the late nineties, codevelopment has been the subject of postgraduate studies, specialist courses, discussions and forums among multiple stakeholders, as well as calls for project grants by some local and regional administrations, beginning with the Municipality of Madrid. These authorities quickly became aware of the local impact of the presence of new immigrant communities, the importance of the links that bind them with their communities of origin, and the desirability of relating them in any future action to support the policies of cooperation. Codevelopment policies had a much stronger presence and development in the regional and local levels.
At the state level, in accordance with Tampere Summit on Migration, the GRECO Plan on migration management (Programa Global de Regulación y Coordinación de la Extranjería y la Inmigración 2000-2004), was launched by the Interior Ministry in 2001. This Plan devoted an important space for “joint development”, in line with the policies of Tampere and the French government. GRECO insisted on technical and educational cooperation, the voluntary return of migrants, the channelling of migrants’ remittances to development projects, and finally, on the cooperation with those governments that were ready to accept the returned illegal migrants, as well as to control the exit of their citizens with destination Spain. However, codevelopment was not even mentioned as a policy line in the Immigration law passed in 2000, and did not receive proper funding within the GRECO’s framework.
Since ending 2004, codevelopment policies have been open to discussion, including the contents, limits, and plans. Two state agencies claimed their space in codevelopment actions: the State Secretary for International Cooperation, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and the brand new General Directorate of Immigrants’ Integration, at the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs.
===Codevelopment policy ===
During 2005 there has been progress in the search for a consensus on competences and actors. A codevelopment line was mainstreamed in the Master Plans on Development Cooperation, and two years later, also in the new Integration Plan, called Strategic Plan on Citizenship and Integration 2007-2010, which was finally implemented in 2007, by the Ministry of Labour and Migration.
Regional and local authorities soon adopted this win/win approach and consequently launched several codevelopment guidelines within their Integration Plans and Development Cooperation Strategies. Ending 2009, most of the Spanish Regions (Comunidades Autónomas) had considered codevelopment and had set up budget lines both for migrants' associations and Development NGOs. Graciela Malgesini argues that codevelopment and migrants' remittances partly redirect the decentralized cooperation funds to their countries of origin.
===Current definitions of codevelopment ===
In the last ten years, academic research on codevelopment increased, as a result of the strong immigration process experienced by the Spanish society from 2000 onwards (which represented nearly 80% of Spain’s demographic growth). Many universities decided to open up new learning courses on the matter, following the steps of the Universidad Autónoma de Madrid. Several doctoral thesis are currently being carried out, focusing diverse aspects of codevelopment, including the impact of migration and remittances in the sending countries, mainly Ecuador, Colombia and Morocco. Migrants living in Spain remitted nearly €10 billion, in 2007 (while the overall Spanish OAD summed only half of this amount).
According to Graciela Malgesini, spontaneous codevelopment could be defined as the win/win effect, the linkage between migration and development, which generates mostly positive impacts on both the society of origin of immigrants, and the host society. This definition presumes the role of immigrants as actors and vectors of development, in "both sides", and the understanding of the relations between host countries (North) and sending countries (South) in a horizontal way. Codevelopment is directly related to Transnationalism.
Carlos Gimenez pinpointed other two characteristics of codevelopment: (1) The multiplicity of stakeholders (a network of participants that surpasses both quantitatively and qualitatively the traditional agents in the traditional development cooperation projects, as it includes authorities, social organizations, trade unions, universities, training institutes, businesses and immigrant associations). (2) Transnational citizenship (immigrants acting in codevelopment activities, embedded in a transnational dynamic, are also transnational citizens, to the extent that they have a dual presence. This dual space of belonging, in turn, encourages decision making, influences on the economic, political and social development, and allows the formation of a separate identity, based on two geographical areas, the country of origin and the country of destination).
===Codevelopment in practice ===
Transnationalism and codevelopment are spreading.In Latin America, covedelopment is a relatively new idea, but it has been embraced by grassroots organizations. For example, on November 25, 2010, FAMIGRANTES—the Federation of associations gathering migrants' family members in South America—gathered in their 4th Meeting on Migration and Codevelopment, in Rosario, Argentina. They stated that the codevelopment approach was the best way of understanding the contribution that their relatives were making both in the reception countries and in their homelands (www.famigrantes.org and www.famisur.org). At the same time, more than 100 migrants' associations launched FEDACOD (Federation of Associations for Codevelopment) in Valencia, Spain, on September 24, 2010 (www.fedacod.com).

The term is used to describe the shape of the [[corniculate cartilages]] of the [[larynx]]. The [[horned puffin]] (''Fratercula corniculata'') is named for its distinctive horn-like coloration. Likewise ''[[Oxalis corniculata]]'' (creeping woodsorrel) is named for its two erect [[capsule (fruit)|capsule]]s, which resemble little horns,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.anbg.gov.au/abrs/online-resources/flora/stddisplay.xsql?pnid=5681|title=Flora of Australia Online|publisher=ABRS}}</ref><ref>See [http://www.ppws.vt.edu/scott/weed_id/oxaco.htm photograph]</ref> and the bird's-foot trefoil ''[[Lotus corniculatus]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.british-wild-flowers.com/bird%27s%20foot%20trefoil%20lotus%20corniculatus,%20l.html|title=030 II Bird's Foot -Trefoil Lotus corniculatus L.|publisher=British-wild-flowers.com}}</ref> and goat's horn mangrove ''[[Aegiceras corniculatum]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.noosanativeplants.com.au/plants/32/aegiceras-corniculatum|title=Noosa's Native Plants:Aegiceras corniculatum}} Note [http://www.noosanativeplants.com.au/images/photos/600x600_Aegiceras%20corniculatum%20050.jpg photo].</ref> are named for their horn-shaped fruits.
